title: Use BTreeMap with u128 values for sparse bit sets/"vectors" (in dataflow etc.).

labels.name: C-enhancement
labels.description: Category: An issue proposing an enhancement or a PR with one.

labels.name: I-compiletime
labels.description: Problems and improvements with respect to compile times.

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: I-compilemem
labels.description: Problems and improvements with respect to memory usage during compilation.

body:
According to our current implementation of B-trees:
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/5965b790142eff7a8546e947914e7a8e00c61575/src/liballoc/btree/node.rs#L53-L55
it would appear that up to `11` key-value pairs can be stored in each node.

For `u128` values representing `128` set elements each, `1408` set elements can be stored in a single allocation, with an overhead of around 50% compared to `Vec<u128>` in the dense case.

Such sparse bitsets would be really useful for (e.g. dataflow) analysis algorithms, in situations where the bitset elements tend to be localized, with multi-"word" gaps in between local groups.

cc @nikomatsakis @pnkfelix
